title: The Large Hadron Collider Is Being Shut Down
description: It's time to wind down.
fullText:
The Large Hadron Collider is going to be shut down ‚Äî not permanently, but for a pretty long time ‚Äî and the famous atom smasher‚Äôs eventual final retirement is also something that top scientists are now considering.

A 16-mile ring-shaped tunnel near the Swiss-French border, the underground particle accelerator is designed to replicate the cosmos‚Äôs extreme conditions shortly after the big bang by whipping up particles to near light speed, at which point physics begins to become extremely weird and counterintuitive.¬†In 2012, scientists used the LHC to discover the existence of the Higgs boson, an elementary particle that, through incredibly esoteric quantum properties, is essentially responsible for giving all other particles their mass.

Even something responsible for one of the most important scientific discoveries in history needs a facelift, however. Beginning in June, engineers will start upgrading the device so that it can carry out ten times the number of particle collisions it currently can do, something that will allow for far more experiments to be conducted, yielding still more troves of data. The project, dubbed the high-luminosity LHC, will take some five years to complete ‚Äî and while surely worth it in the long run, that‚Äôs an immense amount of down time.

Rest assured, the LHC won‚Äôt be going dark without leaving physicists quite a bit of homework to complete before its return, according to Mark Thomson, the new director general of CERN, the intergovernmental organization and physics lab that oversees the particle accelerator.

‚ÄúThe machine is running brilliantly and we‚Äôre recording huge amounts of data,‚Äù Thomson, a professor of experimental particle physics at the University of Cambridge, told The Guardian. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs going to be plenty to analyze over the period. The physics results will keep on coming.‚Äù

The LHC will be offline during almost all of Thomson‚Äôs term, which started on New Year‚Äôs Day. In fact, CERN doesn‚Äôt expect the high-luminosity LHC to be operational again until mid-2030. But while it may sound like Thomson is taking the reins at a less exciting period in the device‚Äôs history, he says he‚Äôs thrilled to be giving it a makeover.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs an incredibly exciting project,‚Äù Thomson told the newspaper. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs more interesting than just sitting here with the machine hammering away.‚Äù

Thomson is also taking charge as CERN is planning the LHC‚Äôs successor. The leading candidate to replace it, per The Guardian, is the gargantuan Future Circular Collider, which at a proposed 56 miles in circumference would make the Hadron look like the kiddie pool. The first stage, designed to smash together electrons and positrons ‚Äî the latter are the former‚Äôs anti-matter counterpart ‚Äî would be built in the late 2040s, with another stage taking its place in the 2070s to accelerate protons to even higher speeds.

The FCC‚Äôs fate, though, is anything but certain. Its slated cost of nearly $19 billion is too much for CERN to pay on its own, according to The Guardian, and there‚Äôs also questions swirling over whether huge particle accelerators represent the best way to probe some of the biggest questions in science, such as the nature of dark matter and dark energy.

Thomson, though, is still a believer in the big atom smasher.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve not got to the point where we have stopped making discoveries and the FCC is the natural progression. Our goal is to understand the universe at its most fundamental level,‚Äù he told The Guardian. ‚ÄúAnd this is absolutely not the time to give up.‚Äù

More on physics: Giant Chinese Orb Detects ‚ÄúGhost Particles‚Äù While Buried Under Mountain

title: China‚Äôs stealth fighter jet approached key Taiwanese airbase without detection: Report
description: A new PLA video appears to show a Chengdu J-20 stealth fighter near Taiwan raises questions less about detection failure than strategic intent.
fullText:
New footage has been released that seems to show a Chinese Chengdu J-20 stealth fighter flying close to a Taiwanese airbase during a recent military exercise. Purportedly taken during the recent ‚ÄúJustice Mission 2025," this has sparked debate as to whether the aircraft was able to approach undetected or not.

‚ÄúChina‚Äôs J-20 stealth fighter flew within visual range of Taiwan‚Äôs coastline. The Taiwanese failed to detect the J-20. It would‚Äôve been a propaganda coup if Taiwan got a photo of the J-20 with their F-16 sniper targeting pod. This happened around Checheng township in Pingtung, at the very southern tip of Taiwan,‚Äù wrote a defence analyst on X.

While hard to confirm, the People's Liberation Army (PLA) has claimed that one of its J-20s managed to fly close to Taiwan's Pingtung airbase. According to reports, this incident occurred on Tuesday (Dec 30) during the second day of the exercise.

It is important to note that these claims have yet to be confirmed by third parties, notably whether the J-20 was actually able to penetrate Taiwanese airspace in the first place.

If true, then such an occurrence would be very worrying for Taiwanese defense forcesm notably how this could happen in the first place. It could, of course, just be a bluff from the PLA to make Taiwan question its defensive readiness against Chinese forces.

While no missiles were fired or lives lost, the supposed incursion by China's fifth-generation J-20 will not be without consequences. Likely, Taiwan will now have to assume worst-case scenarios and spend some time investigating what happened.

They will want to know if the J-20 was able to find radar blind spots in its air defense and take corrective actions accordingly. That will come at a cost for Taiwan.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yLsV8flG1Q4&pp=ygUTSi0yMCBUYWl3YW4gYWlyYmFzZQ%3D%3D

The focus on Pingtung is also interesting as it is one of the nation's key airbases. It has some critical training and sortie-running infrastructure for the Taiwanese air force and is a cornerstone of its air defense.

If China can operate stealth aircraft near that area (even occasionally), it compresses Taiwan‚Äôs reaction time in a real crisis. That is strategically more important than whether this specific flight happened exactly as claimed.

So far, Taiwan has remained silent on the matter, with key officials neither confirming nor denying China's claims. This is likely deliberate to prevent China from taking a public relations victory.

If they deny the claim, this will look to some like Taiwan is covering up for a failure of its air defenses. Confirming the event would also validate PLA propaganda.

Whether the J-20 incursion occurred or not, it has wider implications for the region, too. Firstly, it helps to normalize PLA proximity to Taiwan and blurs peacetime versus wartime behaviour.

It also serves as a training for PLA forces under realistic conditions, and can be used by them to sow doubt and confusion. So while the claim could be fictitious at worst or exaggerated at best, it will have very real impacts on Taiwan one way or the other.

title: Mortgage and refinance interest rates today, January 3, 2026: Almost exactly where they were one week ago
description: These are today's mortgage and refinance rates. Mortgage rates continue to hover within a range and are a fraction over 6%.  Lock in your rate today.
fullText:
Some offers on this page are from advertisers who pay us, which may affect which products we write about, but not our recommendations. See our Advertiser Disclosure.

Mortgage rates today are in familiar territory: almost exactly where they were one week ago. According to Zillow, the average 30-year fixed mortgage rate is 6.01%, and the 15-year fixed rate is just a little lower than last week, at 5.44%.

See which lenders have the best mortgage rates this week.

Here are the current mortgage rates, according to the latest Zillow data:

Remember, these are the national averages and rounded to the nearest hundredth.

Discover 8 strategies for getting the lowest mortgage rates.

These are today's mortgage refinance rates, according to the latest Zillow data:

Again, the numbers provided are national averages rounded to the nearest hundredth. Mortgage refinance rates are often higher than rates when you buy a house, although that's not always the case.

Want to refinance your mortgage in early 2026? Here's what to do.

Use the mortgage calculator below to see how today's interest rates would affect your monthly mortgage payments.

You can bookmark the Yahoo Finance mortgage payment calculator and keep it handy for future use, as you shop for homes and lenders. You also have the option to enter costs for private mortgage insurance (PMI) and homeowners' association dues, if applicable. These details result in a more accurate monthly payment estimate than if you simply calculated your mortgage principal and interest.

There are two main advantages to a 30-year fixed mortgage: Your payments are lower, and your monthly payments are predictable.

A 30-year fixed-rate mortgage has relatively low monthly payments because you‚Äôre spreading your repayment out over a longer period of time than with, say, a 15-year mortgage. Your payments are predictable because, unlike with an adjustable-rate mortgage (ARM), your rate isn‚Äôt going to change from year to year. Most years, the only things that might affect your monthly payment are any changes to your homeowners insurance or property taxes.

The main disadvantage of 30-year fixed mortgage rates is the mortgage interest, both in the short and long term.

A 30-year fixed term comes with a higher rate than a shorter fixed term, and it‚Äôs higher than the intro rate to a 30-year ARM. The higher your rate, the higher your monthly payment. You‚Äôll also pay much 

The pros and cons of 15-year fixed mortgage rates are basically swapped with those of the 30-year rates. Yes, your monthly payments will still be predictable, but another advantage is that shorter terms come with lower interest rates. Not to mention, you‚Äôll pay off your mortgage 15 years sooner. So you‚Äôll save potentially hundreds of thousands of dollars in interest over the course of your loan.

However, because you‚Äôre paying off the same amount in half the time, your monthly payments will be higher than if you choose a 30-year term.

Dig deeper into 15-year vs. 30-year mortgages.

Adjustable-rate mortgages lock in your rate for a predetermined amount of time, then change it periodically. For example, with a 5/1 ARM, your rate stays the same for the first five years and then goes up or down once per year for the remaining 25 years.

The main advantage is that the introductory rate is usually lower than what you‚Äôll get with a 30-year fixed rate, so your monthly payments will be lower. (Current average rates don't necessarily reflect this, though ‚Äî in some cases, fixed rates are actually lower. Talk to your lender before deciding between a fixed or adjustable rate.)

With an ARM, you have no idea what mortgage rates will be like once the intro-rate period ends, so you risk your rate increasing later. This could ultimately end up costing more, and your monthly payments are unpredictable from year to year.

But if you plan to move before the intro-rate period is over, you could reap the benefits of a low rate without risking a rate increase down the road.

Learn whether now is a good time to get an adjustable-rate mortgage.

First of all, now is a relatively good time to buy a house compared to a couple of years ago. Home prices aren't spiking like they were during the height of the COVID-19 pandemic. So, if you want or need to buy a house soon, you should feel pretty good about the current housing market.

The best time to buy is typically whenever it makes sense for your stage of life. Trying to time the real estate market can be as futile as timing the stock market ‚Äî buy when it's the right time for you.

Which is more important, your home price or mortgage rate?

According to Zillow, the national average 30-year mortgage rate is 6.01% right now. Why are Zillow's rates usually lower than those reported by Freddie Mac and elsewhere? Each source compiles rates by different methods. Zillow gets rates from its lender marketplace and Freddie Mac pulls information from loan applications submitted to its underwriting system. Mortgage rates vary by state and even ZIP code, by lender, loan type, and many other factors. That's why it's so important to shop multiple mortgage lenders.

Are interest rates expected to go down?

Not much. According to its December forecast, the MBA expects the 30-year mortgage rate to be near 6.4% through 2026. Fannie Mae also predicts a 30-year rate above 6% through next year, yet dipping down to 5.9% in Q4 2026.

Overall, mortgage rates have dropped gradually since the end of May. The 30-year fixed rate topped out over 7% in January, then bounced higher and lower for months. On May 29, the 30-year rate was 6.89%, and began slowly moving down.

In many ways, securing a low mortgage refinance rate is similar to when you bought your home. Try to improve your credit score and lower your debt-to-income ratio (DTI). Refinancing into a shorter term will also land you a lower rate, though your monthly mortgage payments will be higher.

To refinance your mortgage, you need a certain amount of home equity. The rules vary by loan type and refi program. Learn how much equity you need to refinance.

The best mortgage refinance companies charge low interest rates and fees, and they often have unique perks for customers. Find your best mortgage refinance lender.

If you want to refinance your mortgage before the end of 2025, you're in luck. It may be a good time. Learn the steps to take to refi in the next couple of months.

Mortgage rates are down, so refinancing soon could be a good idea. Learn what to know and how to prepare for refinancing your mortgage at the beginning of 2026.

A mortgage refinance can cost 2% to 6% of the loan amount. Learn what impacts these costs and how to lower or eliminate what you pay up front.

Chase Home Loans is offering a "refinancing rate sale" for rate-and-term and cash-out refinancing. Learn how to qualify for this limited-time rate discount.

title: The Latest: Trump says US will run Venezuela at least temporarily after military option
description: Hours after a dramatic military operation ousted Venezuelan leader Nicol√°s Maduro from power and removed him from the country Saturday, President Donald Trump said the United States would ‚Äúrun‚Äù Venezuela at least temporarily and tap its vast oil reserves to sell to other nations.  U.S. operations on Saturday represented America‚Äôs most assertive action to achieve regime change in a country since the nation‚Äôs 2003 invasion of Iraq.  The middle-of-the-night seizure of Maduro and his wife, Cilia Flores, who were being transported on a U.
fullText:
Hours after a dramatic military operation ousted Venezuelan leader Nicol√°s Maduro from power and removed him from the country Saturday, President Donald Trump said the United States would ‚Äúrun‚Äù Venezuela at least temporarily and tap its vast oil reserves to sell to other nations.

U.S. operations on Saturday represented America‚Äôs most assertive action to achieve regime change in a country since the nation‚Äôs 2003 invasion of Iraq. The actions raise stark new questions about the legality of the U.S. moves under a broader campaign against the South American nation.

The middle-of-the-night seizure of Maduro and his wife, Cilia Flores, who were being transported on a U.S. warship to face narco-terrorism conspiracy charges in New York, is beyond even the most high-profile historical examples of aggressive American actions toward autocratic governments in Panama, Iraq and beyond, legal experts said. It came after a surprise U.S. incursion into the Venezuelan capital, rocked with overnight explosions early Saturday.

The Trump administration described the operation ‚Äî and earlier deadly strikes on boats in the Caribbean Sea ‚Äî as necessary to stem the flow of dangerous drugs.

Protesters gather in Los Angeles, elsewhere to protest US military action

Hundreds gathered in the rain in downtown Los Angeles to protest the U.S. military action in Venezuela.

People donning raincoats and holding umbrellas carried signs saying ‚ÄúStop bombing Venezuela now!‚Äù and ‚ÄúNo blood for oil‚Äù as they listened to speakers. One person held a handwritten sign saying ‚ÄúNo War! No Trump!‚Äù

A smaller group of about 50 people protested in Las Vegas.

Aftermath of US military operation in Venezuela disrupts Caribbean travel

The U.S. military operation that captured Maduro and flew him out of the country has also disrupted Caribbean travel at a busy travel time for the region.

Elisia Cohen had planned to return from her family vacation in Puerto Rico on Friday but a mechanical issue grounded their Delta flight back to Minneapolis. Then, the University of Minnesota professor woke up before dawn Saturday to the news of the strikes on Venezuela and the delay, then cancellations of all flights.

‚ÄúI hope this will not become a nightmare of airspace not opening up,‚Äù she said.

She spent most of Saturday trying to rebook a flight back to anywhere in the continental United States, and even though she succeeded, she said she won‚Äôt truly stop worrying until the airspace reopens and flights start taking off again.

U.S. Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy said in a social media post that ‚Äúthe FAA restricted the airspace in the Caribbean and Venezuela to ensure the SAFETY of the flying public.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhen appropriate, these airspace restrictions will be lifted,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúPlease work with your airlines directly if your flight has been impacted.‚Äù

‚ñ∂ Read more about travel disruptions here

Venezuelans wonder who‚Äôs in charge as Trump claims contact with Maduro‚Äôs deputy Rodr√≠guez

Uncertainty gripped Venezuela on Saturday as people scrambled to understand who was in charge of the South American country.

Trump delivered a shocking pick for who would take control: The United States, perhaps in coordination with one of Maduro‚Äôs most trusted aides.

Delcy Rodr√≠guez has served as Maduro‚Äôs vice president since 2018, overseeing much of Venezuela‚Äôs oil-dependent economy as well as its feared intelligence service. But she is someone the Trump administration apparently is willing to work with, at least for now.

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs essentially willing to do what we think is necessary to make Venezuela great again,‚Äù Trump told reporters of Rodr√≠guez, who faced U.S. sanctions during Trump‚Äôs first administration for her role in undermining Venezuelan democracy.

Trump indicated that Rodr√≠guez had been sworn in already as president of Venezuela, per the transfer of power outlined in the constitution. However, state television has not broadcast any swearing-in ceremony.

In her televised address, Rodr√≠guez did not declare herself acting president or mention a political transition. A ticker at the bottom of the screen identified her as the vice president. She gave no sign that she would be cooperating with the U.S.

‚ÄúWhat is being done to Venezuela is an atrocity that violates international law,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúHistory and justice will make the extremists who promoted this armed aggression pay.‚Äù

‚ñ∂ Read more about the reaction within Venezuela

Maduro‚Äôs ouster sparks celebrations among Venezuelans in South Florida

Revelers chanted ‚Äúliberty‚Äù and draped Venezuelan flags over their shoulders in South Florida to celebrate Maduro‚Äôs capture and removal from the country.

For some Venezuelan natives, the military action ‚Äî culminating months of stepped-up U.S. pressure ‚Äî brought their dreams of reuniting with loved ones closer to reality after years of heartbreaking separations.

People gathered for a rally in Doral, the Miami suburb where Trump has a golf resort and where roughly half the population is of Venezuelan descent.

Outside El Arepazo restaurant, a hub of the Venezuelan culture of Doral, one man held a piece of cardboard with ‚ÄúLibertad‚Äù scrawled with a black marker. It was a sentiment expressed by others hoping for a new beginning for their home country as they chanted ‚ÄúLiberty! Liberty! Liberty!‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre like everybody ‚Äî it‚Äôs a combination of feelings, of course,‚Äù said Alejandra Arrieta, who came to the U.S. in 1997. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs fears. There‚Äôs excitement. There‚Äôs so many years that we‚Äôve been waiting for this. Something had to happen in Venezuela. We all need the freedom.‚Äù

Black lawmakers in Congress condemn ‚Äòillegal‚Äô US actions in Venezuela

The Congressional Black Caucus is blasting Trump over U.S. actions against Maduro, calling the operation ‚Äúa grave and illegal abuse of power.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhile Nicol√°s Maduro is, in fact, an illegitimate leader, the deployment of U.S. military power to impose political change in a sovereign nation ‚Äî without the consent of Congress or a clear and defined plan of action ‚Äî threatens to draw the United States into an indefinite conflict in Venezuela,‚Äù the caucus said in statement.

‚ÄúWe cannot understate the severity of the consequences that could follow from such reckless actions, which threaten regional stability and weaken our standing on the world stage,‚Äù the lawmakers said.

Person in custody seen gingerly leaving plane believed to be carrying Maduro

At around 5:25 p.m., a person in custody was escorted out of the plane believed to be carrying Maduro.

The person gingerly made his way down a stairway one step at a time, then was led across the tarmac surrounded by a crowd of at least three dozen federal agents.

Several agents in the crowd appeared to film the person on their phones.

Canadian PM stands by Venezuelan people‚Äôs sovereign right to build future

Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney says his government welcomes the opportunity for freedom, democracy and prosperity for the Venezuelan people.

Carney notes in a post on a social media that Canada has not recognized the ‚Äúillegitimate regime of Maduro since it stole the 2018 election.‚Äù He says Canada has long supported a ‚ÄúVenezuelan-led transition process that respects the democratic will of the Venezuelan people.‚Äù

Carney is calling on all parties to respect international law and says Canada stands by the ‚ÄúVenezuelan people‚Äôs sovereign right to decide and build their own future.‚Äù

Seizing control of Venezuela‚Äôs oil presents legal issues for US, law professor says

Matthew Waxman, a Columbia University law professor who was a national security official in the George W. Bush administration, said seizing control of Venezuela‚Äôs resources opens up additional legal issues.

‚ÄúFor example, a big issue will be who really owns Venezuela‚Äôs oil?‚Äù Waxman wrote in an email. ‚ÄúAn occupying military power can‚Äôt enrich itself by taking another state‚Äôs resources, but the Trump administration will probably claim that the Venezuelan government never rightfully held them.‚Äù

But Waxman, who served in the State and Defense departments and on the National Security Council under Bush, noted that ‚Äúwe‚Äôve seen the administration talk very dismissively about international law when it comes to Venezuela.‚Äù

JUST IN: Plane carrying deposed Venezuelan leader Nicol√°s Maduro arrives in New York following his capture by US, AP source says German leader calls for stability in Venezuela

Chancellor Friedrich Merz said in a statement Saturday that Nicol√°s Maduro led Venezuela to disaster and noted that Germany, like many other countries, didn‚Äôt recognize his presidency after the South American nation‚Äôs last election.

Merz said that a legal classification of the U.S. intervention is ‚Äúcomplex‚Äù and ‚Äúwe will take time‚Äù on the matter.

He said that political instability must not arise in Venezuela now and that it‚Äôs important to ensure ‚Äúan orderly transition to a government legitimized by elections.‚Äù

Schumer says Trump actions in Venezuela ‚Äòreckless‚Äô

The Senate Democratic leader said, ‚ÄúThe idea that Trump plans to now run Venezuela should strike fear in the hearts of all Americans.‚Äù

Sen. Chuck Schumer of New York said the Trump administration had assured him multiple times it was not pursuing regime change or taking military action in Venezuela.

‚ÄúClearly, they are not being straight with Americans,‚Äù he said.

Rubio hints Cuba could be next after Trump takes Maduro out of Venezuela

Secretary of State Marco Rubio is hinting that Cuba could be the next target of the Trump administration‚Äôs push to restore American dominance in the Western Hemisphere.

Rubio said he would be a bit concerned if he were a Cuban government official following the overnight U.S. military operation in Venezuela that captured Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro and his wife. ‚ÄúIf I lived in Havana and I was in the government, I‚Äôd be concerned at least a little bit,‚Äù said Rubio, who has had a long preoccupation with both Venezuela and Cuba.

The U.S. has had a long history of military interventions in Latin America, including its tacit support for the unsuccessful 1961 Bay of Pigs invasion led by Cuban exiles aimed at toppling Fidel Castro.

Venezuela's UN ambassador says his country has right to self defense

In a letter sent to the U.N. Security Council on Saturday, the Venezuelan ambassador to the U.N. warned that in light of the U.S. strikes, the country ‚Äúreserves the inherent right to self defense.‚Äù

The letter from Ambassador Samuel Reinaldo Moncada Acosta, obtained by AP, goes on to request an urgent meeting of the 15-member council and condemnation and cessation of U.S. actions.

‚ÄúWhat began more than four months ago as a police fantasy is now showing its true face: this is a colonial war aimed at destroying our republican form of government, freely chosen by our people, and at imposing a puppet government that allows the plundering of our natural resources, including the world‚Äôs largest oil reserves,‚Äù Acosta wrote.

Trump says Venezuelan vice president Delcy Rodr√≠guez sworn in as president

U.S. President Donald Trump claimed that Venezuelan vice president Delcy Rodr√≠guez had been sworn in as president shortly before he spoke to reporters and added she had spoken with Secretary of State Marco Rubio.

‚ÄúShe is essentially willing to do what we think is necessary to make Venezuela great again. Very simple,‚Äù Trump said.

Earlier, opposition leader Mar√≠a Corina Machado said that the opposition candidate Edmundo Gonz√°lez should assume power, saying that he rightfully won the 2024 presidential election.

Trump shares photo of captured Maduro

The president posted a photo on social media showing Maduro wearing a sweatsuit and a blindfold with the caption: ‚ÄúNicolas Maduro on board the USS Iwo Jima.‚Äù

Maduro appeared to be wearing a flotation device around his neck. Next to him was someone wearing a jacket that had a DEA logo.

Maduro also had protective headphones on his ears and appeared to be lifting a water bottle with both arms to drink.

Trump‚Äôs action against Maduro contrasts with clemency granted to ex-Honduras leader

Trump‚Äôs dramatic action against Maduro is the polar opposite of the clemency he granted to former Honduran President Juan Orlando Hern√°ndez.

Trump in December pardoned Hern√°ndez though he was sentenced to 45 years in U.S. prison for helping drug traffickers to safely move hundreds of tons of cocaine north through his country to the U.S.

Hern√°ndez, who enjoyed support from officials in the first Trump administration, was convicted by a U.S. jury in New York ‚Äî which Maduro is now set to face.

When asked in an interview with Politico about the pardon, Trump said, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know him‚Äù and ‚ÄúI know very little about him,‚Äù but added that he was told that Hern√°ndez ‚Äúwas set up.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe country, uh, deals in drugs, like probably you could say that about every country, and because he was the president, they gave him like 45 years in prison,‚Äù he said.

Justice Department released a new indictment of Maduro and wife

The indictment accuses Maduro of leading a ‚Äúa corrupt, illegitimate government that, for decades, has leveraged government power to protect and promote illegal activity, including drug trafficking.‚Äù It alleges that the drug trafficking efforts ‚Äúenriched and entrenched Venezuela‚Äôs political and military elite.‚Äù

U.S. authorities allege that Maduro partnered with ‚Äúsome of the most violent and prolific drug traffickers and narco-terrorists in the world‚Äù to bring tons of cocaine into the U.S., according to the indictment.

Authorities estimate that as much as 250 tons of cocaine were trafficked through Venezuela by 2020, according to the indictment. The drugs were moved on go-fast vessels, fishing boats and container ships or via planes from clandestine airstrips, authorities allege.

UN is ‚Äòdeeply alarmed‚Äô by the US strike

The United Nations said it was ‚Äúdeeply alarmed‚Äù by the U.S. strikes and reported detention of President Nicol√°s Maduro in Venezuela. It expressed concern that the escalation was a violation of international law.

‚ÄúThese developments constitute a dangerous precedent,‚Äù St√©phane Dujarric, spokesman for the U.N. secretary-general, said in a statement. Dujarric said the U.N. worried about the larger implications for Latin America and the Caribbean and called on ‚Äúall actors in Venezuela‚Äù to respect human rights and the rule of law.

China slams US strike in Venezuela

China strongly condemned the U.S. strike in Venezuela and the action against its president, the Foreign Ministry said, adding the Beijing government was ‚Äúdeeply shocked‚Äù and firmly opposed to the operation.

‚ÄúSuch hegemonic acts of the U.S. seriously violate international law and Venezuela‚Äôs sovereignty and threaten peace and security in Latin America and the Caribbean region,‚Äù it said.

It called on the U.S. to comply with international law and the principles of the U.N. Charter, urging it to stop violating the sovereignty and security of other nations.

Trump says a helicopter was hit and ‚Äòa few‚Äô US members were injured in Venezuela

Trump said a helicopter was hit during the operation in Venezuela and a few U.S. members were injured, but he believed none were killed.

‚ÄúA couple of guys were hit, but they came back and they‚Äôre supposed to be in pretty good shape,‚Äù he said.

He said the U.S. lost no aircraft in the operation.

‚ÄúWe got it all back. One of them was hit pretty hard but‚Äîa helicopter‚Äîbut we got it back.

‚ÄúWe had to do it because it‚Äôs a war,‚Äù he added a few moments later.

Trump dismisses criticism he did not seek congressional permission for Venezuela strike

Trump brushed off criticism from U.S. Democratic lawmakers that he did not seek permission from Congress ahead of time and that the strike was illegal. He called his Democratic critics ‚Äúweak, stupid people‚Äù and blaming his political opponents for inflation in the U.S.

He said the operation in Venezuela was ‚Äúreally genius.‚Äù

‚ÄúAll they do is complain,‚Äù he said of the Democrats.

‚ÄúThey should say, ‚ÄòGreat job.‚Äô They shouldn‚Äôt say, ‚ÄòOh Gee, maybe it‚Äôs not constitutional.‚Äô You know, the same old stuff that we‚Äôve been hearing for years and years and years,‚Äù Trump said.

Trump says he proposed to the Mexican president that US take out cartels

Trump said the operation in Venezuela ‚Äúwasn‚Äôt meant to be‚Äù a message to Mexico, but then he has proposed to Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum that the U.S. ‚Äútake out‚Äù cartels in her country and suggested the U.S. might take action.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre very friendly with her, she‚Äôs a good woman. But the cartels are running Mexico. She‚Äôs not running Mexico. The cartels are running Mexico,‚Äù Trump said.

He said he‚Äôs asked Sheinbaum numerous times, ‚ÄúWould you like us to take out the cartels?‚Äù but she has said no.

‚ÄúSomething‚Äôs going to have to be done with Mexico,‚Äù Trump said.

Trump says US will decide on what‚Äôs next for Venezuela

President Donald Trump said in an interview Saturday morning that the United States will be making decisions on what is next for Venezuela after capturing the Latin American country‚Äôs president and flying him out of the country.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll be involved in it very much‚Äù as to who will govern the country, Trump said.

‚ÄúWe can‚Äôt take a chance in letting somebody else run and just take over what he left, or left off,‚Äù Trump said in an interview with Fox News hours after the capture.

Maduro was at his home when he was seized in US operation, party leader tells AP

Venezuelan ruling party leader Nahum Fern√°ndez told The Associated Press that Nicol√°s Maduro and his wife were at their home within the Ft. Tiuna military installation when they were captured.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs where they bombed,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúAnd, there, they carried out what we could call a kidnapping of the president and the first lady of the country.‚Äù

European leaders react to Maduro‚Äôs capture by the US

‚Äî EU foreign policy chief Kaja Kallas wrote on X that she had spoken with U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio and the EU ambassador in Caracas. ‚ÄúThe EU has repeatedly stated that Mr Maduro lacks legitimacy and has defended a peaceful transition. Under all circumstances, the principles of international law and the UN Charter must be respected. We call for restraint.‚Äù

‚Äî Spanish Prime Minister Pedro S√°nchez called for ‚Äúde-escalation and responsibility. International Law and the principles of the United Nations Charter must be respected,‚Äù S√°nchez wrote on X.

‚Äî Russia‚Äôs Foreign Ministry said it is ‚Äúextremely alarmed‚Äù and called for ‚Äúimmediate clarification,‚Äù according to a statement posted Saturday on the ministry‚Äôs Telegram channel. The ministry said such actions, if confirmed, would constitute ‚Äúan unacceptable infringement on the sovereignty of an independent state.‚Äù

‚Äî British Prime Minister Keir Starmer said the U.K. was not involved in the U.S. operation in Venezuela and that he would seek more information from Trump. Without condemning the U.S. action, Starmer said he always believes that international law should be upheld. ‚ÄúBut I think at this stage, fast moving situation, let‚Äôs establish the facts and take it from there,‚Äù he said.

US indicted Maduro on narcoterrorism charges in 2020

The Justice Department during Trump‚Äôs first term in office charged in the several indictments that Maduro had effectively converted Venezuela into a criminal enterprise at the service of drug traffickers and terrorist groups as he and his allies stole billions from the South American country.

The coordinated unsealing of indictments against 14 officials and government-connected individuals, and rewards of $55 million for Maduro and four others, attacked all the key planks of what then-Attorney General William Barr called the ‚Äúcorrupt Venezuelan regime,‚Äù including the Maduro-dominated judiciary and the powerful armed forces.

One indictment by prosecutors in New York accused Maduro and socialist party boss Diosdado Cabello, head of the rubber-stamping constitutional assembly, of conspiring with Colombian rebels and members of the military ‚Äúto flood the United States with cocaine‚Äù and use the drug trade as a ‚Äúweapon against America.‚Äù

Read our news report from 2020 on the charges

Russia calls US action ‚Äòan act of armed aggression‚Äô

Russia‚Äôs Foreign Ministry condemned what it called a U.S. ‚Äúact of armed aggression‚Äù against Venezuela in a statement posted on its Telegram channel Saturday.

‚ÄúVenezuela must be guaranteed the right to determine its own destiny without any destructive, let alone military, outside intervention,‚Äù the statement said.

The ministry called for dialogue to prevent further escalation and said it reaffirmed its ‚Äúsolidarity‚Äù with the Venezuelan people and government, adding that Russia supports calls for an emergency U.N. Security Council meeting.

title: What to know about the protests now shaking Iran as tensions remain high over its nuclear program
description: Widening protests in Iran sparked by the Islamic Republic's ailing economy are putting new pressure on its theocracy.  Tehran is still reeling from a 12-day war launched by Israel in June that saw the United States bomb nuclear sites in Iran.  Economic pressure, intensified in September by the return of United Nations sanctions on the country over its atomic program, has put Iran's rial currency into a free fall, now trading at some 1.4 million to $1.
fullText:
DUBAI, United Arab Emirates (AP) ‚Äî Widening protests in Iran sparked by the Islamic Republic's ailing economy are putting new pressure on its theocracy.

Tehran is still reeling from a 12-day war launched by Israel in June that saw the United States bomb nuclear sites in Iran. Economic pressure, intensified in September by the return of United Nations sanctions on the country over its atomic program, has put Iran's rial currency into a free fall, now trading at some 1.4 million to $1.

Meanwhile, Iran's self-described ‚ÄúAxis of Resistance‚Äù ‚Äî a coalition of countries and militant groups backed by Tehran ‚Äî has been decimated in the years since the start of the Israel-Hamas war in 2023.

A new threat by U.S. President Donald Trump warning Iran that if Tehran ‚Äúviolently kills peaceful protesters,‚Äù the U.S. ‚Äúwill come to their rescue" has taken on new meaning after American troops captured Venezuelan President Nicol√°s Maduro, a longtime ally of Tehran.

Here's what to know about the protests and the challenges facing Iran's government.

How widespread the protests are

Demonstrations have reached over 170 locations in 25 of Iran‚Äôs 31 provinces, the U.S.-based Human Rights Activists News Agency reported early Sunday. The death toll had reached at least 15 killed, it added, with more than 580 arrests. The group, which relies on an activist network inside of Iran for its reporting, has been accurate in past unrest.

Understanding the scale of the protests has been difficult. Iranian state media has provided little information about the demonstrations. Online videos offer only brief, shaky glimpses of people in the streets or the sound of gunfire. Journalists in general in Iran also face limits on reporting such as requiring permission to travel around the country, as well as the threat of harassment or arrest by authorities.

But the protests do not appear to be stopping, even after Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei on Saturday said ‚Äúrioters must be put in their place.‚Äù

The collapse of the rial has led to a widening economic crisis in Iran. Prices are up on meat, rice and other staples of the Iranian dinner table. The nation has been struggling with an annual inflation rate of some 40%.

In December, Iran introduced a new pricing tier for its nationally subsidized gasoline, raising the price of some of the world‚Äôs cheapest gas and further pressuring the population. Tehran may seek steeper price increases in the future, as the government now will review prices every three months.

The protests began first with merchants in Tehran before spreading. While initially focused on economic issues, the demonstrations soon saw protesters chanting anti-government statements as well. Anger has been simmering over the years, particularly after the 2022 death of 22-year-old Mahsa Amini in police custody that triggered nationwide demonstrations.

Iran's ‚ÄúAxis of Resistance," which grew in prominence in the years after the 2003 U.S.-led invasion and subsequent occupation of Iraq, is reeling.

Israel has crushed Hamas in the devastating war in the Gaza Strip. Hezbollah, the Shiite militant group in Lebanon, has seen its top leadership killed by Israel and has been struggling since. A lightning offensive in December 2024 overthrew Iran‚Äôs longtime stalwart ally and client in Syria, President Bashar Assad, after years of war there. Yemen's Iranian-backed Houthi rebels also have been pounded by Israeli and U.S. airstrikes.

China meanwhile has remained a major buyer of Iranian crude oil, but hasn't provided overt military support. Neither has Russia, which has relied on Iranian drones in its war on Ukraine.

The West worries about Iran‚Äôs nuclear program

Iran has insisted for decades that its nuclear program is peaceful. However, its officials have increasingly threatened to pursue a nuclear weapon. Iran had been enriching uranium to near weapons-grade levels prior to the U.S. attack in June, making it the only country in the world without a nuclear weapons program to do so.

Tehran also increasingly cut back its cooperation with the International Atomic Energy Agency, the U.N.'s nuclear watchdog, as tensions increased over its nuclear program in recent years. The IAEA's director-general has warned Iran could build as many as 10 nuclear bombs, should it decide to weaponize its program.

U.S. intelligence agencies have assessed that Iran has yet to begin a weapons program, but has ‚Äúundertaken activities that better position it to produce a nuclear device, if it chooses to do so.‚Äù

Iran recently said it was no longer enriching uranium at any site in the country, trying to signal to the West that it remains open to potential negotiations over its atomic program to ease sanctions. But there's been no significant talks in the months since the June war.

Why relations between Iran and the US are so tense

Iran decades ago was one of the United States‚Äô top allies in the Mideast under Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi, who purchased American military weapons and allowed CIA technicians to run secret listening posts monitoring the neighboring Soviet Union. The CIA fomented a 1953 coup that cemented the shah‚Äôs rule.

But in January 1979, the shah, fatally ill with cancer, fled Iran as mass demonstrations swelled against his rule. Then came the Islamic Revolution led by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, which created Iran‚Äôs theocratic government.

Later that year, university students overran the U.S. Embassy in Tehran, seeking the shah‚Äôs extradition and sparking the 444-day hostage crisis that saw diplomatic relations between Iran and the U.S. severed.

During the Iran-Iraq war of the 1980s, the U.S. backed Saddam Hussein. During that conflict, the U.S. launched a one-day assault that crippled Iran at sea as part of the so-called ‚ÄúTanker War,‚Äù and later shot down an Iranian commercial airliner that the U.S. military said it mistook for a warplane.

Iran and the U.S. have seesawed between enmity and grudging diplomacy in the years since, and relations peaked with the 2015 nuclear deal, which saw Iran greatly limit its program in exchange for the lifting of sanctions. But Trump unilaterally withdrew America from the accord in 2018, sparking tensions in the Mideast that intensified after Hamas' Oct. 7, 2023, attack on Israel.

title: Tommy Lee Jones' Daughter Victoria Was Offered Plea Deal Before Death
description: Tommy Lee Jones' daughter Victoria had a plea deal that demanded sobriety waiting to be signed ahead of her sudden death ... TMZ has learned.
fullText:
Tommy Lee Jones' daughter Victoria had a plea deal that demanded sobriety waiting to be signed ahead of her sudden death ... TMZ has learned.

As you know, she was found deceased at Fairmont San Francisco early Thursday morning, with the dispatch audio indicating it may be related to an overdose. We also told you she had multiple run-ins with the law over the years ... with a recent drug-related arrest in April.

And, according to court docs obtained by TMZ ... Victoria was offered a plea deal following the April incident, during which she was found to be in unlawful possession of cocaine -- and resisted arrest. The plea deal Napa County had offered would require her to plead guilty to resisting/obstructing arrest and possessing a controlled substance ... but would free her of the charge against her of being under the influence of a controlled substance. In return, she'd have to refrain from using drugs and submit to random testing.

This deal would have required her to be on probation for a year ... as well as attend an alternative program such as counseling. She would have also been responsible for paying for the program as well as the fines associated with her charges.

Victoria's next court date was January 20, where she may have entered a plea for the case. However, she did not make it to the date.

TMZ reached out to Victoria's attorney and the Napa County prosecutor for comment ... so far, no word back.

As we told you, the charges resulted from a welfare check at Victoria's location after she accidentally dialed police in Napa. She told authorities she was fine, but while there, they noticed a white residue on her tongue and that she had rapid speech and was "fighting with her body movements." She admitted to using cocaine that day, and police arrested her -- which she resisted.

Victoria's family broke their silence on her death Friday with a brief statement that read ... "We appreciate all of the kind words, thoughts, and prayers. Please respect our privacy during this difficult time. Thank you."

title: New York Jets vs. Buffalo Bills: 3 X-factors on defense for Week 18
description: Identifying three potential X-factors for the New York Jets defense against the Buffalo Bills in Week 18.
fullText:
The New York Jets will play their Week 18 finale versus the Buffalo Bills on Sunday.

It'll represent the last showing for a defense that must undergo a serious identity makeover in the offseason. Head coach Aaron Glenn will hire a new defensive coordinator. General manager Darren Mougey will also be tasked with acquiring more talented playmakers on defense. They are heavily outmatched heading into Sunday.

Until then, we've identified three potential X-factors for the Jets defense in Week 18.

Jermaine Johnson II hasn't recorded a sack in his latest six appearances. It's been tough sledding for the pass rusher who returned from a 2024 season-ending torn Achilles injury. Johnson continues playing with effort, so it would be nice to see him finish the season with a breakthrough.

Interim defensive coordinator Chris Harris recently heaped praise on linebacker Jamien Sherwood. Sherwood leads the Jets in tackles by a longshot with 147 takedowns this season. Despite it being a lost season, he continues to compete to his full capabilities.

Veteran defensive tackle Harrison Phillips has been a limited participant at practice this week. That indicates he's trending towards being available for Sunday's finale. The Jets need Phillips' run-stopping efforts against Josh Allen and James Cook.

This article originally appeared on Jets Wire: New York Jets vs. Buffalo Bills: 3 X-factors on defense for Week 18

title: What Seahawks vs. 49ers means for the Rams‚Äô NFC playoff standings
description: Week 18 will determine whether the Rams lock up the 5 or 6 seed in the NFC. Here‚Äôs where things stand heading into the final week of the NFL season.
fullText:
We‚Äôre heading into the final week of the 2025 NFL season, and the Rams won‚Äôt know where they stand for the postseason until we get to the other side of it.

As of right now, the Rams are slotted in at the No. 6 Wild Card spot, but things could shift depending on how Saturday‚Äôs late game between the Seahawks and 49ers shakes out. If the Seahawks win on Saturday, and the Rams beat the Cardinals on Sunday, then LA can wrap up the fifth seed. That would involve traveling to face the four-seed, which will be the NFC South winner. The Buccaneers are penciled into that spot right now after Saturday afternoon‚Äôs win over the Panthers, but they now need the Falcons to lose to the Saints on Sunday to cement their NFC South win.

If the Rams lose and the 49ers win, the Rams will stay in the sixth seed. In that case, they‚Äôll play either the Eagles or the Bears to kick off the postseason, and I think it goes without saying that the 5-seed is the better option here.

Here are the updated standings before Saturday‚Äôs games kick off in Week 18.

1. Seattle Seahawks (13-3) ‚Äì Clinched playoff spot
2. Chicago Bears (11-5) ‚Äì¬†Clinched NFC North
3. Philadelphia Eagles (11-5) ‚Äì¬†Clinched NFC East
4. Carolina Panthers (8-8)
5. San Francisco 49ers (12-4)¬†‚Äì Clinched playoff spot
6.¬†Los Angeles Rams (11-5)¬†‚Äì Clinched playoff spot
7. Green Bay Packers (9-6-1)¬†‚Äì Clinched playoff spot

title: Will Fred Warner return for playoffs? Latest injury update on 49ers linebacker
description: San Francisco 49ers linebacker Fred Warner has a chance to make it back on the field in the playoffs. Here's the latest injury update on the star linebacker's status.
fullText:
Will Fred Warner return for playoffs? Latest injury update on 49ers linebacker originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

We haven't seen San Francisco 49ers star linebacker Fred Warner on a football field in quite some time.

That's because Warner suffered a broken and dislocated ankle back in Week 6 that was supposed to completely end his season.

However, there is renewed hope that Warner will make it back during the playoffs, although the Niners are going to have to win at least a game or two for that to be a possibility.

Yes, there is a chance Warner will play in the postseason.

But for that to even be a possibility, the Niners will have to make it to the NFC Championship Game or Super Bowl, as NFL Network's Ian Rapoport reported.

Rapoport does add, however, that Warner would likely be limited if he does make it back during the playoffs, and he's more likely to be back by the Super Bowl rather than the NFC title game.

"Sources informed of Warner's situation say there is a chance that Warner's rehab could be going well enough for him to make a cameo in the NFC Championship Game if San Francisco is a participant or more likely Super Bowl LX, should it win the conference title," Rapoport and Garafolo wrote. "And even then, it would likely be in spot duty. Any early return might put him at risk of further injury."

Even if Warner is just limited upon his return, simply having him in uniform would provide a huge jolt to the 49ers at the most crucial moment of the season.

title: Texas A&M MBK secures 75-72 victory over LSU in SEC opener
description: Texas A&M head coach Bucky McMillan secured his first SEC win in College Station, as the Aggies defeated the LSU Tigers on Saturday.
fullText:
Texas A&M's first-year head coach gave the LSU Tigers men's basketball program a first-hand look at what "Bucky Ball" is all about, as the Aggies captured their first Southeastern Conference win of the Bucky McMillan era at Reed Arena on Saturday.

The Maroon and White commanded the lead for the majority of the contest, but a late charge by Matt McMahon's squad resulted in a back-and-forth battle in the closing moments of the contest. Another outstanding performance from Rashaun Agee helped send the Tigers back to Baton Rouge, Louisiana, with their first loss of conference play, as the graduate forward secured a double-double by leading the team with 15 points and 11 rebounds in the 75-72 win over LSU. Guards Rub√©n Dominguez and Pop Isaacs combined for 24 points, while Ali Dibba secured 12 off the bench.

Texas A&M shot 41.9% from the field and 71.4% from the free-throw line as a unit. The Aggies' high-paced attack outscored the Tigers, 18-7, in fast-break points.

Tigers met Bucky Ball üëç#GigEm | @optimum pic.twitter.com/PXEW1Kz40P

‚Äî Texas A&M Basketball (@aggiembk) January 3, 2026

McMillan has his team out to a four-game winning streak and a 1-0 record to begin SEC play. While the Aggies must continue to improve from range, as the team shot just 28.6% from beyond the arc in the win, there are a plethora of exhilarating playmakers in Bryan-College Station, Texas, who want to turn the program around this season. Texas A&M moved to 11-3 with the first victory of the new year, but league play presents more difficult challenges ahead, including games against six teams currently ranked in the top 25.

The Aggies' next SEC contest takes place on Tuesday, Jan. 6, as McMillan's squad faces the Auburn Tigers at Neville Arena in Auburn, Alabama. Tip-off against the Tigers is set for 8 p.m. CT and will be broadcast live on the SEC Network.

Contact/Follow us¬†@AggiesWire¬†on X¬†(formerly Twitter) and like our page on¬†Facebook¬†to follow ongoing coverage of Texas A&M news, notes and opinions.¬†Follow Dylan on X:¬†@dylanmflippo.

This article originally appeared on Aggies Wire: Texas A&M MBK secures 75-72 victory over LSU in SEC opener

title: Twenty-Three Years Later: Miami‚Äôs Sweet Revenge Comes Full Circle with a Punch to Ohio State‚Äôs Mouth
description: Before moving ahead to Ole Miss, revisiting Miami‚Äôs emphatic punch that knocked out the defending national champions.
fullText:
Tonight is the 23rd anniversary of the most controversial call in college football history, and three nights ago Miami finally got its revenge.

No. 10 Miami shocked No. 2 Ohio State 24-14 in the Cotton Bowl, ending the Buckeyes‚Äô quest to become the first repeat national champion in the 12-team playoff era, and the first since Georgia in 2021-2022 and Alabama in 2011-2012. The 9.5-point upset wasn‚Äôt just one of the biggest in the CFP era, but it was poetic justice 23 years in the making. It also set the tone on a weekend where Ohio State, Georgia, and Alabama all lost, marking a changing of the guard in college football.

Redemption for the Hurricanes 23 years later. pic.twitter.com/PyBsd1o84G

‚Äî Mike Kennedy (@MikeKennedyNFL) January 1, 2026

And before moving on to a challenging Ole Miss opponent, it‚Äôs important to cherish the juxtaposition from this year‚Äôs New Year‚Äôs Eve to that night 23 years ago. In 2003, Ohio State ended Miami‚Äôs 34-game winning streak and stopped the defending champions from repeating. On Tuesday night, Miami returned the favor, stopping Ohio State‚Äôs own repeat bid with the exact same formula the Buckeyes used against them two decades ago.

For a program haunted by Terry Porter‚Äôs controversial pass interference flag in overtime of the 2003 Fiesta Bowl ‚Äì the call that gave Ohio State new life and eventually a 31-24 national championship victory- this wasn‚Äôt just a win. It was redemption. It was closure. It was sweet, intoxicating revenge.

‚ÄúI was full of emotions,‚Äù said cornerback Keionte Scott after his 72-yard pick-six gave Miami a 14-0 lead. ‚ÄúI think I took a little moment to peek at the [Ohio State] sideline and look at everybody and let them know what was going on.‚Äù

The Miami Hurricanes blow away the defending champs üå™Ô∏èüò±

Miami shocks the No. 2 Ohio State Buckeyes in the Cotton Bowl Classic üôå pic.twitter.com/favaquJZHO

‚Äî FOX College Football (@CFBONFOX) January 1, 2026

That sideline included this year‚Äôs Heisman finalist, Julian Sayin, who looked petrified throughout the night. That sideline included Ryan Day, who had no answer for Mario Cristobal‚Äôs trenches. And that sideline included Caden Curry, who came up with a hypothetical that Ohio State would beat Miami 9 out of 10 times if they played. A pointless hypothetical that Miami fans have been hearing throughout this postseason and one that was not at all a reality on Wednesday night.

The Canes sideline, however, included Miami legends Jimmy Johnson, Michael Irvin, and Ray Lewis ‚Äì witnesses to The U‚Äôs most satisfying victory in a generation.

The parallels between these two games are almost eerie, as if college football‚Äôs karma finally came full circle after 22 years. StateOfTheU‚Äôs own, Rob Weaver, discussed them in his feature leading up to the Cotton Bowl.

In 2003, Ohio State rode an elite defense featuring future NFL stars like Mike Doss, Will Smith, AJ Hawk, and Cie Grant. That defense held Miami‚Äôs star-studded offense ‚Äì Willis McGahee, Clinton Portis, Andre Johnson, Kellen Winslow Jr., and Ken Dorsey ‚Äì to just 24 points in regulation, controlled the clock, and physically dominated the defending champions.

In 2025, Miami used a similar blueprint. The Hurricanes‚Äô defense, led by a diesel front of Akheem Mesidor and All-American Rueben Bain, Jr., held Ohio State to nine yards in the first quarter and sacked freshman quarterback Julian Sayin five times. They forced turnovers, including the epic Keionte Scott pick six. They punched the Buckeyes in the mouth ‚Äì time and time again ‚Äì until Ohio State had nothing left, including Jakobe Thomas who made future first rounder Carnell Tate cower under the bright lights, recording just three receptions for 37 yards. Sure, Miami native Jeremiah Smith was electric but he chose to chase waterfalls while Miami continues to build something special (the grass isn‚Äôt always greener Jeremiah, and you still have eligibility to right that wrong ‚Äì but that‚Äôs for another day). The haymakers Miami threw continuously throughout the night were 23 years in the making.

Watch this Ohio State staffer trying to get Jeremiah Smith away from all the Miami love pic.twitter.com/ppa7SB0HNP

‚Äî CaneSport Miami Hurricanes (@CaneSport) January 1, 2026

The 2002 Buckeyes had Craig Krenzel, a game manager who let the defense dominate. Miami had Carson Beck, who completed 19 of 26 passes with zero turnovers and managed the game to perfection. Clean and efficient from start to finish. Neither quarterback was spectacular but each made the plays when needed. Krenzel made a key 17-yard pass on fourth-and-14 in overtime while Beck had an enormous run on third-and-long in the fourth. Both were exactly what their teams needed.

Ohio State in 2003 controlled the clock and won with methodical, grinding football, outrushing the Canes 145 yards to 65 yards. Miami in 2025 rushed for 131 yards on 40 carries, with Mark Fletcher Jr. earning offensive MVP honors. When Ohio State closed to 17-14 in the fourth quarter, Miami responded with a 10-play, 70-yard drive that consumed over five minutes and ended with CharMar Brown‚Äòs game-sealing touchdown. Flipping the script from 2003, the 2025 Miami gathered 153 rush yards to the Buckeyes‚Äô 45.

Keionte Scott is such a complete player. Over 13 TFLs this year, and this time, the elite play recognition shows up on the pick-six.

Making game-changing plays with his processing-fueled aggression.

 pic.twitter.com/MskHkfF3Ao

‚Äî Ian Cummings (@IC_Draft) January 1, 2026

It was championship football ‚Äì physical, relentless, suffocating. The kind of football Ohio State used to break Miami‚Äôs hearts in 2003. The kind of football Miami used to break Ohio State‚Äôs dynasty dreams in 2025.

The Hurricanes didn‚Äôt just beat Ohio State. They beat them the way Ohio State beat Miami in 2003, by punching them in the mouth until the defending champions crumbled.

Understanding what makes this victory so sweet requires understanding what was stolen from Miami on that January night in 2003.

The 2001 Miami team has a legitimate argument as the greatest college football team ever assembled. The 2002 squad was almost as talented, riding a 34-game winning streak into the Fiesta Bowl as 11.5-point favorites ‚Äì the near 10-point spreads in each game being another parallel. The Buckeyes were defending their championship against a program that hadn‚Äôt won a title in 32 years.

If Miami had won that game ‚Äì if Terry Porter‚Äôs flag had never been thrown ‚Äì the trajectory of college football might have been completely different. This is a little less of a hypothetical than the malarkey that Caden Curry and Notre Dame fans (regarding their playoff omission) have been spewing. Back-to-back titles could have cemented Miami as the dynasty of the 2000s. Recruits would have kept flowing to Coral Gables. The U would have maintained its throne.

Instead, the dynasty died that night. The 2003 Fiesta Bowl shaped the trajectories of both programs. Ohio State went 103-24 following that victory with multiple Big Ten titles, while Miami went 77-48 in the years after.

The Miami Hurricanes are heading to the CFP Semifinals after a huge upset win over the Ohio State Buckeyes.

WHAT. A. WIN. üèÜ üôåüèª

(üì∏ @LuFromdade) pic.twitter.com/OV1oPTXTBO

‚Äî The Kevin Harlan Effect (@KevHarlanEffect) January 1, 2026

USC rose to prominence the very next season. Ohio State built their modern powerhouse on the foundation of that championship, playing in five national title games since 2003 and winning two more. Miami fell from grace almost immediately, never winning an ACC championship after joining in 2004, spending two decades trying to recapture lost glory.

The 2003 Fiesta Bowl didn‚Äôt just end Miami‚Äôs winning streak. It ended their dynasty. Ohio State built theirs on the ruins.

For 22 years, Miami fans have carried that pain. They‚Äôve watched Willis McGahee‚Äôs knee get destroyed. They‚Äôve replayed Ken Dorsey‚Äôs final incomplete pass. They‚Äôve raged about Terry Porter‚Äôs delayed flag. They‚Äôve watched Ohio State thrive while The U struggled to be relevant.

Tuesday night, Miami finally got to return the favor ‚Äì and it felt glorious.

Perhaps the most poetic detail of Miami‚Äôs revenge? The Hurricanes will face No. 6 Ole Miss in the Fiesta Bowl semifinals on January 8.

The Fiesta Bowl. Yup, Miami‚Äôs first appearance in that stadium (kinda) since the night Terry Porter‚Äôs flag changed everything. Their first time playing in Glendale, Arizona since January 3, 2003 ‚Äì when they left as heartbroken runners-up, their dynasty in ruins.

One of the best reps of his career pic.twitter.com/GaRQvmmUlw

‚Äî art (@canefilms) January 1, 2026

Now they return as giant slayers, having just ended Ohio State‚Äôs repeat bid the same way the Buckeyes ended theirs. They return with an elite defense punching opponents in the mouth and the capability to beat anyone in the nation if they repeat what they did Wednesday. They return with legends like Jimmy Johnson, Michael Irvin, and Ray Lewis believing again. Not only those legends, but the many Hurricanes who believed in Miami during the last two decades.

They return one win away from a national championship game at Hard Rock Stadium ‚Äì their home field ‚Äì where they could complete the most improbable redemption story in college football history.

Back in March, Michael Irvin posted about ‚Äústumping on the grave of that PASS Interference ghost.‚Äù That ghost has been exorcised. The pain has been washed away. The score has been settled. Irvin not only stomped on em, but he put that belt to ass.

This is me ‚Å¶@OhioStateFB‚Å© stumping on the grave of that PASS Interference ghost (RIP-my ass) that cheated us out of our üôåüèæ fam (‚Å¶@CanesFootball‚Å© ) CHAMPIONSHIP !!!!THATS TWO RINGS I LOST ON BAD P.I. CALLS!!!! pic.twitter.com/L80WBjIrKs

‚Äî Michael Irvin (@michaelirvin88) March 31, 2025

The symmetry is almost too perfect: Ohio State ruined Miami‚Äôs title repeat in the 2003 Fiesta Bowl. Miami ruined Ohio State‚Äôs title repeat and now returns to the Fiesta Bowl to continue their championship run. The hunter became the hunted. The wounded became the avenger. The dynasty that was stolen might just be reborn.

For Miami fans who have carried 22 years of anger, who have argued and who have wondered ‚Äúwhat if‚Äù a thousand times ‚Äì this victory means everything.

It means The U is back ‚Äì not just competitive, but dangerous. Not just relevant, but feared. Not just hoping to recapture the past, but building something new while honoring what was lost. Mario Cristobal‚Äôs greatest strength ‚Äì recruiting ‚Äì has only been enhanced even more by proving his ability to secure quality wins and increase player development (this latter part has been on display not only with Francis Mauigoa and Bain, but also OJ Frederique, Malachi Toney, and Bryce Fitzgerald, among many other contributing underclassmen).

Miami Hurricanes: Cotton Bowl Champions pic.twitter.com/H5uytB5Fh0

‚Äî CFB Kings (@CFBKings) January 1, 2026

Ohio State came in as 9.5-point favorites, the defending national champions with dynasty aspirations. Miami punched them in the mouth for 60 minutes ‚Äì the same way Ohio State punched Miami 22 years ago ‚Äì and sent them home with their repeat dreams shattered.

The 2025 Hurricanes used 2003 Ohio State‚Äôs own formula against them: elite defense, game management, physical football, and relentless pressure. They beat the defending champions at their own game, in the biggest upset in CFP history, and earned a return trip to the stadium where their dynasty died.

Now Miami heads back to the Fiesta Bowl ‚Äì not as 11.5-point favorites defending a championship, but as 3.5-point favorites trying to complete one of the greatest revenge stories college football has ever seen, especially after stubbing their toe against the likes of Louisville and SMU during this season and nearly squandering their playoff chances. One more win in Glendale, and they‚Äôll play for a national championship at home in Miami Gardens.

‚ÄúGo pick all yall homeboys up off the field‚Äù üòÇüòÇ pic.twitter.com/skHMrpGXJF

‚Äî Top Tier Miami (@TopTierCanes) January 2, 2026

The dynasty that was stolen in the 2003 Fiesta Bowl might just be resurrected in the 2025 Fiesta Bowl. The punch Ohio State threw 23 years ago finally got answered. The Canes continue their return to the promised land with their second big boy bowl in two weeks, countering the lone New Year‚Äôs Six they‚Äôve played in the last two decades (an uninspiring 34-24 Orange Bowl loss to Wisconsin in 2017).

The pain is over. The revenge is complete. And somehow, impossibly, Miami gets to return to the scene of their greatest heartbreak to continue their championship run. The job is not finished.

Regardless, as it relates to Ohio State, after 23 years of waiting it feels like justice to return to Arizona.

The Hurricanes are back. And this time, they‚Äôre the ones doing the punching. We‚Äôre onto Ole Miss.

title: Baker Mayfield and the Buccaneers beat the Panthers 16-7 and stay alive in chase for NFC South title
description: The winner of the NFC South will have a losing record and be crowned at home watching on television.
fullText:
The winner of the NFC South will have a losing record and be crowned at home watching on television.

Baker Mayfield threw a touchdown pass to Cade Otton, Chase McLaughlin kicked three field goals and the Tampa Bay Buccaneers avoided elimination with a sloppy 16-14 victory over the Carolina Panthers on a rain-soaked Saturday.

The Buccaneers (8-9) need New Orleans (6-10) to beat or tie Atlanta (7-9) on Sunday to clinch a fifth straight NFC South title.

If the Falcons win, the Panthers (8-9) will secure their first division championship since coach Ron Rivera and quarterback Cam Newton led them to a 15-1 record and a Super Bowl appearance 10 years ago.

ALSO READ: George Li‚Äôs analytics expertise helps drives Panthers‚Äô fourth-down efficiency

The Buccaneers hold a two-team tiebreaker over the Panthers. But Carolina holds the three-team tiebreaker over Tampa Bay if Atlanta also finishes 8-9.

Before the Buccaneers faced New Orleans in October, Mayfield accused the Saints of dirty play and said: ‚ÄúI do not like them.‚Äù

Now, Tampa Bay‚Äôs playoff hopes hinge on the Saints beating the Falcons on the road on Sunday.

The Buccaneers were 0-8 in games where Mayfield threw an interception before overcoming his ninth pick in the last eight games.

After McLaughlin‚Äôs 38-yard field-goal try was blocked with just over five minutes remaining, Carolina got within 16-14 on Bryce Young‚Äôs 8-yard TD pass to Jalen Coker with 2:27 left.

Mayfield tossed a short pass to Otton for a 20-yard gain on third-and-4 to extend Tampa Bay‚Äôs drive and run off more time. The Panthers got the ball back at their 3 with 18 seconds and no timeouts left. The game ended on a desperate series of laterals that resulted in a fumble.

Mayfield connected with Otton on an 18-yard TD pass for a 7-0 lead as the Bucs scored a touchdown on their opening drive for the third straight game. It was Otton‚Äôs first TD of the season.

Down 10-0, the Panthers turned Christian Rozeboom‚Äôs interception into a quick score. Rozeboom returned the pick 20 yards to Tampa Bay‚Äôs 19. Young then connected with Tommy Tremble on an 8-yard TD pass to cut it to 10-7.

Jacob Parrish picked off Young late in the second half and the Buccaneers got a 36-yard field goal from McLaughlin to take a 13-7 halftime lead.

McLaughlin kicked a 48-yard field goal early in the fourth to extend Tampa Bay‚Äôs lead.

Carolina‚Äôs Ryan Fitzgerald missed a 54-yarder short on the opening drive of the third quarter.

Mayfield completed his first six passes before misfiring on a cross-field, 13-yard toss to Payne Durham, who was wide open in the end zone. The Bucs settled for McLaughlin‚Äôs 29-yard field goal and a 10-0 lead.

Gene Deckerhoff, the voice of the Buccaneers for 37 years on radio, is retiring after the season. Six-time Pro Bowl wide receiver Mike Evans and veteran linebacker Lavonte David could have played their last game with the Buccaneers and possibly in the NFL if they choose to retire.

David was a second-round pick in 2012, made one Pro Bowl, was a first-team All-Pro once and second team All-Pro twice.

Evans, the No. 7 overall pick in 2014, had a 1,000-yard season every year of his career until this one, when he broke his clavicle in October and missed several games.

Panthers: DT Bobby Brown III (head) left the game to be evaluated for a concussion.

Buccaneers: LB Anthony Walker (ankle) was injured on the opening kickoff. ... CB Jamel Dean (shoulder) and OLB Anthony Nelson (knee) didn‚Äôt play. ... DT Calijah Kancey (pectoral) was active for the first time since Week 2.

Panthers: Host a wild-card game or start the offseason.

Buccaneers: Host a wild-card game or start the offseason.

VIDEO: Channel 9 sits down with Panthers defensive star Nic Scourton ahead of NFC South title clash

title: Pregame news from Santa Clara: Josh Jones starting LT before kick at 49ers
description: The veteran swing tackle had missed practices this week with ankle and knee injuries. He‚Äôs starting again for injured Charles Cross.
fullText:
After a scare earlier this week, the Seahawks aren‚Äôt down to their undrafted rookie third-string left tackle, after all.

Josh Jones was the starter in place of injured Charles Cross for the third consecutive week Saturday, in pregame drills about a half hour before Seattle kicked off at the San Francisco 49ers for the NFC West title.

Jones had been questionable to play. He missed practices Tuesday and Wednesday with ankle and knee issues. Coach Mike Macdonald said the veteran swing tackle had gotten ‚Äúbanged up a little‚Äù last weekend in the Seahawks‚Äô win at Carolina.

Jones began trending toward playing when he practiced on a limited basis Thursday.

The team signed rookie free agent Amari Kight from the practice squad to the active roster earlier this week, as insurance. He was backing up Jones in pregame drills Saturday.

Macdonald said Friday the Seahawks believe Cross will be able to play in their first playoff game. He‚Äôs been out since he injured his hamstring on Jason Myers‚Äô game-winning field goal on the final play Dec. 14 against Indianapolis.

There were no surprises in Seattle‚Äôs inactive players for the game Saturday.

They were quarterback Jalen Milroe, injured starting safety Coby Bryant, linebacker Jared Ivey, Cross, rookie offensive linemen Bryce Cabledue and Mason Richman and rookie tight end Nick Kallerup.

Ty Okada was poised to start again for Bryant, who has a knee injury. It was to be Oakada‚Äôs 11th start the season. The first nine was when safety Julian Love was out injured.

title: What Kansas State coach Jerome Tang said after losing to BYU
description: The Cougars scored a 83-73 win over Kansas State in Saturday‚Äôs Big 12 opener.
fullText:
Prior to Saturday, Kansas State had only lost four times at home against ranked opponents in the Jerome Tang era.

But after BYU‚Äôs visit to Manhattan, Tang now has five such losses with the Wildcats.

The No. 10-ranked Cougars scored a 83-73 win over Kansas State in Saturday‚Äôs Big 12 opener, marking BYU‚Äôs first 10-game win streak since the days of Jimmer Fredette more than a decade ago.

‚ÄúObviously, BYU is a terrific team, and Kevin (Young) does a great job and was very proud of our guys‚Äô effort,‚Äù Tang told reporters postgame.

‚ÄúWe have to continue to get better. To win or lose this game, we have to get better. We have some glaring things that are standing out, but they‚Äôre correctable. I know our guys‚Äô heart, so I know that we will improve in the areas that we need to.‚Äù

The Wildcats were top 10 nationally in 3-point shooting team prior to Saturday, but against the Cougars they made just 3 of 21 attempts from behind the arc.

‚ÄúWell, they didn‚Äôt go in, you know, the ones that we took, they weren‚Äôt bad shots,‚Äù Tang said. ‚ÄúI thought we turned down like four or five that we should have been ready to shoot, that we weren‚Äôt ready to shoot. Some of that‚Äôs a credit to (BYU‚Äôs) length, right, those closeouts, but some of it, you know, I don‚Äôt know why we didn‚Äôt take certain shots that we‚Äôd have normally taken.

‚ÄúI said at one point, ‚ÄòMan, we can‚Äôt make 3s if we don‚Äôt shoot them,‚Äô you know. That‚Äôs one of the strengths of our team, and so, you know, a lot of credit goes to BYU, because of the percentage of 3s that we took, as opposed to 2s, it‚Äôs too great. We got to look at the film and figure that out.‚Äù

Kansas State did force 19 total BYU turnovers, but such defensive success wasn‚Äôt enough to upset the Cougars.

‚ÄúWe wanted to be the more aggressive team. It was great, but when you force 19 turnovers, you can‚Äôt have 17 points off (them). You need to have 27 points off of it, because there are a lot of them were live ball turnovers, and so we‚Äôve got to capitalize,‚Äù Tang said.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think that we capitalized on that, and I thought that they controlled the pace of the game in the second half. We didn‚Äôt play fast enough. We didn‚Äôt.‚Äù

BYU superstar AJ Dybantsa, once a Kansas State recruiting target, dazzled once again in his first taste of Big 12 action, scoring 24 points with eight rebounds, three assists and three steals.

With his 24 points, Dybantsa is now the country‚Äôs leading scorer at 23.1 points per game.

AJ DYBANTSA vs K State 

24 PTS 
7 REB 
3 AST 
3 STL pic.twitter.com/ZTqK6Z20ZY

‚Äî BYU Men's Basketball (@BYUMBB) January 3, 2026

‚ÄúYou know, I‚Äôve been watching AJ since he was in the seventh grade, and love him and his family. You know, I had a great time recruiting him,‚Äù Tang said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve watched his games this season, and he‚Äôs been one of the most efficient players, and today, he was very efficient again, you know, scoring 24 points on 15 shots.‚Äù

Kansas State now falls to 9-5 on the season and 0-1 in Big 12 play, with a tough road trip to No. 1 Arizona and Arizona State coming up next.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm hoping (our players) walk away with confidence that if that‚Äôs a top 10 team (in) the country and the team people say can win a national championship, and we didn‚Äôt play close to what we‚Äôre capable of playing, then, I mean, the ceiling is high, and so we should be really confident, excited about getting back into practice and improving them,‚Äù Tang said.

title: 49ers-Seahawks discussion: Brock Purdy and the offense will be shorthanded
description: Demarcus Robinson for Ricky Pearsall, while Eric Kendricks could see his first extended action.
fullText:
The San Francisco 49ers will wear their all-black rival jerseys tonight against the Seattle Seahawks. Brock Purdy and the offense won‚Äôt have their most dangerous wide receiver or all-everything left tackle.

The Seahawks are already stingy enough, but being short-handed at two of the most critical positions will make Kyle Shanahan, Brock Purdy, and everybody else‚Äôs job on offense much more challenging.

If there‚Äôs anybody who can devise a game plan without Trent Williams and Ricky Pearsall, it‚Äôs Shanahan. George Kittle and Christian McCaffrey will earn their paychecks tonight. McCaffrey might catch 15 passes if that‚Äôs what it takes for the offense to move the ball.

How can Robert Saleh and the 49ers defense rise to the occasion? Bryce Huff will face a backup left tackle. It would be a great time for rookies Alfred Collins and CJ West to generate pressure. That‚Äôs the best way to spook Sam Darnold, who is prone to batted passes and throwing off his backfoot when pressured up the middle.

Darnold threw the ball to the Panthers on the first play of the game. They dropped it. That‚Äôs been an issue for the 49ers‚Äô defensive backs this season. If there were ever a time to redeem themselves, it‚Äôs Week 18 with the No. 1 seed on the line.

Based on warm-ups, Eric Kendricks will see some action at SAM linebacker. That makes the 49ers more athletic at the second level without sacrificing size against the run. Offensively, it looks like Demarcus Robinson will get the start in place of Pearsall.

title: Stanford beats No. 13 Louisville, gets first ranked win in Kyle Smith era
description: Stanford earned an 80-76 win against No. 13 Louisville on Jan. 2. Here's how it happened
fullText:
Stanford men's basketball had its first game of the new calendar year and opened it with a shocking 80-76 win against No. 13 Louisville on Jan. 2 at Maples Pavilion in Stanford, California.

It was the biggest victory for Stanford head coach Kyle Smith, who earned his first ranked win at Stanford. It was also the first time in program history that Stanford beat Louisville.

Freshman guard Ebuka Okorie led Stanford with 28 points, finishing 9-for-18 from the field and made 8-of-10 free throw attempts. Senior forward Chisom Okpara scored 17 points and notched a season-high eight rebounds, two assists, two blocks and two steals.

Redshirt junior Ryan Agarwal scored 12 points, making all four of his 3-point attempts.

"Great win for the program," Smith said told reporters after the game. "We needed it. Some guys made some big efforts. Obviously, Ebuka was tremendous. But you know, Ryan going 4-for-4 from 3 was very helpful."

Smith said after watching film, with some guys getting called out for their efforts and performance, the team responded.

"They really bought in to what we're trying to do," Smith said. "From the getgo I thought we were pretty competitive in trying to take away 3s from those guys. They're a really explosive offense and a good defensive team."

Okorie has scored at least 20 points in eight games for Stanford. He is ranked No. 10 in Division I basketball in points per game, averaging 21.5.

The 6-foot-2 guard is third out of all freshmen in scoring behind Duke forward Cameron Boozer and BYU forward AJ Dybantsa.

"After watching film, I noticed I needed to be more aggressive. Whether it's getting downhill, getting my teammates involved (or) creating for myself," Okorie told reporters after the game. "I feel like that's what I did today and it helped us get the win."

Stanford improves to 12-3 this season and 1-1 in the ACC. Its next game is on the road at Virginia Tech on Wednesday, Jan. 7. The game will be televised on ACC Network.

This article originally appeared on USA TODAY: Stanford basketball vs Louisville score, highlights
